Constant Field Values

Grid_Style

public java.lang.String[] Grid_Style
null, or an array of 3 strings, which determine the default number/letter style for grids. Grid_Style[0] for left, Grid_Style[1] for top Grid_Style[2] for bottom The strings should be "A" "1" or "A1" or null if null, a default of {"1",null,"A"} will be used for diagonal_grid or a default of {null,"A1","A1"} for normal grid will be supplied.

isTorus

public boolean isTorus
if isTorus is true, the edges of the board will be connected to create an edgeless board. I'm not sure if this makes sense for non-square boards. At present (7/2006) this is actually implemented for hex boards for use by Hive.

drawing_style

public int drawing_style
values for drawing_style determine how the board is drawn around the grid points. Most modern boards use STYLE_NOTHING which draws nothing.

unlinkCell

public void unlinkCell(cell C)
unlink this cell bidirectionally, effectively removing it from the board. this is used to create holes in the board, like the center square in tzaar This also removes C from "allCells", but not from teh cell array

Parameters:
C -

public void sameboard(gBoard from_b)

closestCell

public cell closestCell(HitPoint highlight,
                        java.awt.Rectangle brect)
find the closest cell on the board. For many cases, this is preferable to checking each cell for closeness to the mouse, because there are no gape or overlaps in the result.

Parameters:
highlight -
brect -
Returns:

closestCell

public cell closestCell(int x,
                        int y)
find the closest cell to a given x,y. This is used to determine what the mouse is pointing at without leaving any gaps between cells. If the mouse is not "near" any cell, return null. This isn't quite enough for torroidal boards that wrap around.

Parameters:
x -
y -
Returns:

encodeCellPosition

public java.awt.Point encodeCellPosition(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         double cellsize)
find the closest cell and encode the x,y as a position relative to the cell grid. The result includes a flag so we know the position should be decoded the same way.

Overrides:
encodeCellPosition in class BaseBoard
Returns:
a point
See Also:

See Also:
encodeCellPosition

SetDisplayParameters

public void SetDisplayParameters(double scale,
                                 double yscale,
                                 double xoff,
                                 double yoff,
                                 double rot,
                                 double xperspec,
                                 double yperspec,
                                 double skew)
// this sets the basic parameters of the board, to determine the location of the cell grid points within the rectangle. For simple boards, this is just scale and offset. With all the parameters, it can be used to match the grid points to an arbitrary piece of artwork. Unfortunately these parameters are not independently adjustable, so to match artwork some experimentation is required to zero in on the desired grid.

Parameters:
scale - overall scale (normal 1.0)
yscale - y scale relative to overall scale (normal 1.0)
xoff - x offset in units of cells
yoff - y offset in units of cells
rot - rotation in degrees clockwise
xperspec - x forshortening as a function of y (0 is no effect)
yperspec - y forshortening as a function of y (0 is no effect)
skew - x multiply as a percentage of y

yCellRatio

public double yCellRatio()

yGridRatio

public double yGridRatio()

SetDisplayRectangle

public void SetDisplayRectangle(java.awt.Rectangle r)
adjust the internal scaling parameters so the board displays inside the specified rectangle. This works by running a trial transformation of all the points on the board, then scaling the result to completely fill the rectangle if possible.

Parameters:
r -

DrawGridCoord

public void DrawGridCoord(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                          java.awt.Color clt,
                          int xpos,
                          int ypos,
                          int cellsize,
                          java.lang.String txt)
this is an overridable method of the board, used to draw the grid coordinates. This allows arbitrary adjustments to fit the artwork.

emptyColumn

public java.awt.Point emptyColumn()
find an empty column. This is used for boards that are linked into a torus, so the best starting point may not be at A1

Returns:

cellToXY

public java.awt.Point cellToXY(char thiscol,
                               int dispRow,
                               java.awt.Rectangle tbRect)
calculate an XY for col,row, wrapped by the board rectangle and spanning distances. this is used for torridal boards where the visual can wrap. It won't work for boards with perspective.

Parameters:
thiscol -
dispRow -
tbRect -
Returns:
